elements.name: panel4
elements.title: Kavin and Dorothea have been married for twelve years and have three children aged between five and eleven. Now they have grown apart and both want a divorce. A friend has told them that they need to file for divorce.

elements.name: question1
elements.title: Is that true?
elements.correctAnswer: No, they can also jointly apply to the court for a divorce. They submit an agreement (convention) to the court.

elements.name: question2
elements.title: What consequences of the divorce do Kavin and Dorothea have to settle in the divorce agreement? Which consequences of the divorce do they not have to settle?
elements.correctAnswer: The divorce agreement must regulate: custody, maintenance contributions, division of assets and jointly saved pension contributions (AHV, occupational benefits, etc.). However, the following does not need to be regulated: the future place of residence.

elements.name: question3
elements.title: What happens if Kavin and Dorothea only agree on some of the consequences of the divorce? Do they then have to file a lawsuit?
elements.correctAnswer: No, in the case of disputed points, the spouses can still jointly request a divorce and declare that the consequences of the divorce on which they disagree should be assessed by the court.

elements.name: question4
elements.title: What is the legal situation if Kavin and Dorothea have been living apart for some time, but still live in the same home and only Dorothea wants a divorce? Can Dorothea go ahead with the divorce against Kavin's wishes?
elements.correctAnswer: Yes, she must file for divorce with the court. After the separation, Kavin can prevent the divorce for a maximum of two years.
